ARTICLE.TITLE: Central Texas elementary shares look at the start of an 'unusual school year'
ARTICLE.TEXT:
Central Texas elementary shares look at the start of an 'unusual school year'

Photos of spaced out cafeterias and masked elementary school kids were shared on Wednesday by Thrall Elementary, a campus in Thrall, which is about 30 minutes east of Round Rock. In a letter to parents, Thrall ISD Superintendent Tommy Hooker said he recognized "that this will be an unusual school year, but we remain committed to supporting your student's learning, as well as his or her safety." less Photos of spaced out cafeterias and masked elementary school kids were shared on Wednesday by Thrall Elementary, a campus in Thrall, which is about 30 minutes east of Round Rock. In a letter to parents, Thrall ... more Photo: Thrall Elementary School Photo: Thrall Elementary School Image 1 of / 9 Caption Close Central Texas elementary shares look at the start of an 'unusual school year' 1 / 9 Back to Gallery

Months after the 2019-2o2o school year was cut short because of the coronavirus pandemic, kids in Williamson County are back on campus, but it looks different than how they left it.

Photos of spaced out cafeterias and masked elementary school kids were shared on Wednesday by Thrall Elementary, a campus in Thrall, which is about 30 minutes east of Round Rock.

RELATED: San Antonio's COVID-19 risk level is now steady, 'but still much higher than we need it to be'

In a letter to parents, Thrall ISD Superintendent Tommy Hooker said he recognized "that this will be an unusual school year, but we remain committed to supporting your student's learning, as well as his or her safety."

All schools in the district will follow prevention protocols like screening all staff, students and visitors. Every faculty member and student is also required to wear a face mask. If a COVID-19 case is confirmed on campus, areas heavily used by the individual will be closed off and disinfected, those in contact with the person will be notified as well as the local health department, according to the district's website.

The district included protocols for each level of learning. For the elementary, all collaborative spaces were eliminated and students are supervised in the lunch line to ensure social distancing. Recess will still happen, but the kids will be required to wear their face masks and wash their hands afterwards, the plan says.

The school shared Facebook photos of what the plan looked like in action.

"Masks on, socially distanced, no problem," the post reads.

Thrall, which has a population of about 953 people, has one active COVID-19 case, 29 recoveries and one death, according to the city website.

Madalyn Mendoza covers news and puro pop culture for MySA.com | mmendoza@mysa.com | @maddyskye
